articles.headline: BP Is Barred From Taking Government Contracts
articles.snippet: The Environmental Protection Agency said it was taking the action because of BP’s “lack of business integrity,” which it said was demonstrated by the 2010 Deepwater Horizon blowout and oil spill.
articles.abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency said it was taking the action because of BP’s “lack of business integrity,” which it said was demonstrated by the 2010 Deepwater Horizon blowout and oil spill.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States government has temporarily banned the British oil company BP from new federal contracts, citing the company’s “lack of business integrity.”
articles.byline: By John M. Broder and Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Hot Gift Is a Tablet, but Which to Buy?
articles.snippet: There seems to be a different tablet for every man, woman, child and mutant. We offer a rundown on e-readers, tablets and mini-tablets for holiday gift-givers.
articles.abstract: There seems to be a different tablet for every man, woman, child and mutant. We offer a rundown on e-readers, tablets and mini-tablets for holiday gift-givers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The other day, I joined NPR for a segment about high-tech holiday gifts. I was ready for the calls from listeners. I’d brushed up on cameras, phones, laptops, music players and game consoles. I was prepared to talk about limiting screen time, digital addiction, cyberbullying. I knew where to get the best deals.

articles.headline: In Silicon Valley, Technology Talent Gap Threatens G.O.P. Campaigns
articles.snippet: It doesn’t take an algorithm to deduce that those who would donate to a campaign might also be those who would consider working for it.
articles.abstract: It doesn’t take an algorithm to deduce that those who would donate to a campaign might also be those who would consider working for it.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO – I live in Brooklyn, where President Obama won 81 percent of the vote this month. It’s hard to find anywhere in the country that is more Democratic-leaning.

articles.headline: As Official Drops Out, S.E.C. Race Shifts
articles.snippet: After Mary J. Miller, a senior Treasury Department official, removed her name from consideration, Sallie L. Krawcheck, a longtime Wall Street executive, has emerged as a potential front-runner to head the S.E.C.
articles.abstract: After Mary J. Miller, a senior Treasury Department official, removed her name from consideration, Sallie L. Krawcheck, a longtime Wall Street executive, has emerged as a potential front-runner to head the S.E.C.
articles.lead_paragraph: The field of candidates to run the Securities and Exchange Commission is shifting after a contender dropped out of the race.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: For United, Big Problems at Biggest Airline
articles.snippet: Two years after its merger with Continental, United Airlines has struggled with delays and computer glitches, and it has failed to settle on a contract with employees — all while losing money.
articles.abstract: Two years after its merger with Continental, United Airlines has struggled with delays and computer glitches, and it has failed to settle on a contract with employees — all while losing money.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — It was supposed to be a moment for celebration: United Airlines observing the delivery of its second Boeing 787 Dreamliner with a flight from Seattle to Chicago earlier this month for a select group of employees, while senior officers, including Jeffery A. Smisek, United’s hard-charging chief executive, served Champagne and took lunch orders.

articles.headline: U.S. Weighs Bolder Effort to Intervene in Syria’s Conflict
articles.snippet: The Obama administration, hoping that the war in Syria has reached a turning point, is considering more aggressive action there, including providing arms to some opposition fighters.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration, hoping that the war in Syria has reached a turning point, is considering more aggressive action there, including providing arms to some opposition fighters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration, hoping that the conflict in Syria has reached a turning point, is considering deeper intervention to help push President Bashar al-Assad from power, according to government officials involved in the discussions.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Costliest Jet, Years in Making, Sees the Enemy: Budget Cuts
articles.snippet: The F-35 Joint Strike Fighter, still plagued by technological troubles, will ultimately cost taxpayers $396 billion if the Pentagon sticks to its plan.
articles.abstract: The F-35 Joint Strike Fighter, still plagued by technological troubles, will ultimately cost taxpayers $396 billion if the Pentagon sticks to its plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON PARK, Md. — The Marine version of the F-35 Joint Strike Fighter, already more than a decade in the making, was facing a crucial question: Could the jet, which can soar well past the speed of sound, land at sea like a helicopter?

articles.headline: Big Issues Are Lost in Focus on Libya Talking Points
articles.snippet: The parsing of four sentences, rather than important questions about the Benghazi killings, could decide the fate of a leading candidate for secretary of state, Susan E. Rice.
articles.abstract: The parsing of four sentences, rather than important questions about the Benghazi killings, could decide the fate of a leading candidate for secretary of state, Susan E. Rice.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three days after the lethal attack on the American Mission in Benghazi, Libya, Representative C. A. Dutch Ruppersberger of Maryland, the top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee, asked intelligence agencies to write up some unclassified talking points on the episode. Reporters were besieging him and other legislators for comment, and he did not want to misstate facts or disclose classified information.

articles.headline: Medicare Is Faulted on Shift to Electronic Records
articles.snippet: A sharply critical report says the agency has not put in place safeguards against fraud and abuse in encouraging the switch to electronic medical records.
articles.abstract: A sharply critical report says the agency has not put in place safeguards against fraud and abuse in encouraging the switch to electronic medical records.
articles.lead_paragraph: The conversion to electronic medical records — a critical piece of the Obama administration’s plan for health care reform — is “vulnerable” to fraud and abuse because of the failure of Medicare officials to develop appropriate safeguards, according to a sharply critical report to be issued Thursday by federal investigators.

articles.headline: U.S. Growth Revised Up, but Year-End Slowdown Is Feared
articles.snippet: The Commerce Department increased its estimate of third-quarter economic growth from a 2 percent annual rate, but economists do not see that level continuing.
articles.abstract: The Commerce Department increased its estimate of third-quarter economic growth from a 2 percent annual rate, but economists do not see that level continuing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even though government figures showed on Thursday that the economy grew faster than first estimated in the third quarter, economists warned that the pace of expansion could slow drastically in the final months of the year amid the fiscal standoff in Washington and growing caution on the part of businesses.

articles.headline: U.N. Assembly, in Blow to U.S., Elevates Status of Palestine
articles.snippet: More than 130 countries voted to recognize Palestine as a nonmember observer state, a stinging defeat for Israel and the United States and a boost for President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority.
articles.abstract: More than 130 countries voted to recognize Palestine as a nonmember observer state, a stinging defeat for Israel and the United States and a boost for President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — More than 130 countries voted on Thursday to upgrade Palestine to a nonmember observer state of the United Nations, a triumph for Palestinian diplomacy and a sharp rebuke to the United States and Israel.
articles.byline: By Ethan Bronner and Christine Hauser
